title: Seventh Chords
description: Learn dominant 7th, major 7th, and minor 7th chords — adding richness and color to your harmony.

steps.title: Adding the 7th
steps.description:
Seventh chords add a fourth note on top of a triad. There are three main types:

• Dominant 7th (C7): major triad + minor 7th — bluesy, wants to resolve
• Major 7th (Cmaj7): major triad + major 7th — smooth, jazzy
• Minor 7th (Cm7): minor triad + minor 7th — warm, mellow

steps.title: Play C7 (Dominant 7th)
steps.description: Play C, E, G, Bb. The dominant 7th has a strong 'pull' — it wants to resolve to the I chord (F major).

steps.title: Play Cmaj7 (Major 7th)
steps.description: Play C, E, G, B. The major 7th sounds dreamy and sophisticated.
steps.hint: C (60) + E (64) + G (67) + B (71). Note: B natural, not Bb!

steps.title: Play Cm7 (Minor 7th)
steps.description: Play C, Eb, G, Bb. Minor 7th chords have a warm, soulful quality.

steps.title: Play G7 (Dominant 7th)
steps.description: G7 is the most important dominant chord in the key of C. Play G, B, D, F.

steps.title: Dominant Resolution
steps.description: The dominant 7th chord (V7) creates tension that resolves beautifully to the I chord. Try playing G7 → C major. This V7 → I movement is the strongest resolution in music and ends almost every classical piece.
